Fig. 1 Illustration of a SCILL catalyst in this work. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 TEM images and particle size for 2N15Cu. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 BSE-SEM-EDS mapping for N15Cu and 2N15Cu catalysts. The colours indicate copper (blue) and alumina (red). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Conversions of (a) octanal and octene, and (b) selectivity of 1-octanol and C16 diol obtained over 2N-15Cu with the effect of temperature. Conditions: 50 bar, 18 h−1 LHSV and 1:2 octanal: hydrogen ratio. Standard deviation for all data values are ±1.2 mol%. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Summary of the effect of weight loading over 2N15Cu SCILL catalyst. Reaction conditions: 160 °C, 50 bar, 9 h−1 LHSV. Standard deviation on all data values are ±0.5 mol%. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 SEM-EDS line scans over the fresh 2N15Cu SCILL (a) BSE image, (b) line scan of Al (red), Cu (blue), and S (green), and (c) line scan of Cu and S, and the used 2N15Cu SCILL showing (d) BSE Image, (e) line scan of Al, Cu, and S, and (f) line scan of Cu and S. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Effect of liquid hourly space velocity for the competitive octanal/octene hydrogenation over the 2N15Cu SCILL catalyst containing 10 wt% [BMIM][NTf2]. Reaction conditions: 160 °C, and 50 bar. Standard deviation for all data values are ±0.2 mol%. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Time-on-line study for the competitive octanal/octene hydrogenation over the 2N15Cu SCILL catalyst containing 10 wt% ionic liquid. Reaction conditions: 2 mL catalyst, 160 °C, 50 bar, 9 h−1 LHSV. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Illustration depicting the interfaces between the bulk liquid and the feed-ionic liquid, and the ionic liquid and the solid catalyst. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Summary of the octanol selectivity, octanal conversion and octene conversions obtained over the 2N15Cu (uncoated), 2N15Cu SCILL (hexane solvent), and 2N15Cu SCILL (OL washed). Standard deviation for all values are ±0.5 mol%. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 XPS spectra of (a) Cu 2p, (b) Al 2p, (c) Al 2p fitted, (d) O 1s, (e) O 1s fitted for the 2N15Cu, 2N15CU SCILL and 2N15Cu SCILL used catalysts. Fig. 11 Fig. 12 XPS spectra of (a) N 1s, (b) C 1s, (c) C 1s fitted, (d) S 2p, (e) S 2p, and (f) F 1s for the 2N15Cu, 2N15Cu SCILL and used 2N15Cu SCILL catalysts. Fig. 12 Table 1 Summary of TPR data for Cu catalysts. Table 1 Catalyst Peak 1/°C Peak 2/°C Reducibility/% a N15Cu 202 233 82 2N15Cu 209 238 87 a The degree of reducibility = (Moles H2 consumed/Moles reducible Cu) * 100. The effect of ionic liquid on alumina supported copper catalysts for the competitive hydrogenation of octanal in the presence of octene Letisha Naicker a Holger B. Friedrich a ⁎ Alisa Govender b Pheladi Mohlala b a Catalysis Research Group, School of Chemistry and Physics, University of KwaZulu-Natal, Durban 4000, South Africa Catalysis Research Group School of Chemistry and Physics University of KwaZulu-Natal Durban 4000 South Africa b R&T, Analytics, Group Technology, Sasol South Africa (Pty) Ltd, Sasolburg 1947, South Africa R&T, Analytics, Group Technology Sasol South Africa (Pty) Ltd Sasolburg 1947 South Africa ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The influence of 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium bis(trifluromethanesulfonyl)imide ([BMIM][NTf2]) on Cu/γ-Al2O3 was investigated for the competitive hydrogenation of octanal in the presence of octene in a continuous flow reactor. The role of the solid catalyst was investigated by comparing the activities of one-step (N15Cu) vs two step (2N15Cu) wet impregnated catalyst. Characterization techniques included nitrogen physisorption, temperature programmed studies, electron microscopy and X-Ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy which were used to determine the catalyst properties and metal-ionic liquid interaction of the uncoated and IL coated catalysts. The Cu SCILL catalyst (solid catalyst with an ionic liquid layer) showed enhanced catalytic performance as compared to the uncoated catalyst. Under optimized conditions, the 2N15Cu SCILL catalyst favoured the desired hydrogenation of the octanal, whilst minimizing the undesired octene hydrogenation. The octene conversion decreased from 26% to 6% over the SCILL catalyst. The presence of the ionic liquid also increased the selectivity towards the desired product, 1-octanol, from 93.5% over the uncoated catalyst to 99.8% over the SCILL catalyst. Investigation into the interaction between the copper and the ionic liquid revealed that the ionic liquid is physically adsorbed onto the catalyst’s surface, and induced changes in the SCILL catalysts surface acidity, BET surface area and hydrogen-metal interaction. It seems likely that the thermal and chemical properties of the ionic liquid also contributed to the SCILL catalyst behaviour, for example, the polar nature of the ionic liquid favours the diffusion of octanal as opposed to octene within the ionic liquid layer. This results in a greater selectivity towards CO hydrogenation which is desired. Keywords SCILL Ionic liquid Copper Selective hydrogenation Liquid phase 1 Introduction Hydrogenation of organic molecules with unsaturated functional groups is of great interest in the petrochemical, pharmaceuticals and fine chemistry industries [1,2]. The selective hydrogenation of mixed feeds is an industrially relevant reaction, which has applications e.g. in the hydroformylation and polymer industries. After the hydroformylation reaction, there may be minor amounts of unreacted alkenes which can pass through to the aldehyde hydrogenation process, which converts the alkenes to alkanes of lower value [3,4]. Thus, the selective hydrogenation of the CO bond over the CC bond is desirable. Similar to this application, many catalytic systems have been investigated for the selective hydrogenation of α,β-unsaturated aldehydes. It was found that precious metals such as Pt and Pd favour the hydrogenation of the CC bond, while Cu favours the hydrogenation of the CO bond [2,5–8]. Copper has also been found to preferentially adsorb and activate the CO bond as opposed to the CC bond under hydrogenolysis conditions [9–14]. It is known that the CC bond hydrogenates faster than the CO bond. According to Marinellini and Ponec [15] this is due to the dative CO bond being weaker than the π-complexing of the CC bond to the active site. The dative bond could be strengthened if the metal bears a slight positive charge, increasing the interaction between the carbonyl oxygen and the active site, thus favouring the CO hydrogenation. Changing the electron density of the metal using a promoter, second metal, or additive has been studied extensively for various catalytic systems. Results showed that an increase in electron density can cause the active site to repel the π-bonds in the CC functional group, thus favouring the adsorption of the CO functional group [16]. Apart from the electronic interaction between the unsaturated functional group and the metal, there is also variation in how the functional group adsorbs onto the active site. A number of studies have investigated the possible adsorption modes and reaction pathways of CO and CC functional groups for their hydrogenation. Sitthisa et al. [17] investigated the possible reaction pathways of the CO function group on copper, stating that the preferred mode of adsorption is the η1 (O)-aldehyde atop mode. An et al. [18] also looked at the reaction pathways for carbonyl hydrogenation and concluded that the hydrogenation occurs through the alkoxy pathway on the Cu (111) surface. One route of altering the surface adsorption properties of a heterogeneous catalyst is with the use of an ionic liquid (IL). This type of catalyst system is often referred to as supported ionic liquid catalysis, where there are many variations such as supported ionic liquid phase (SILP) and solid catalyst with an ionic liquid layer (SCILL) [19–21]. The ionic liquid can affect the catalyst in two ways, either a physical solvent effect or a ligand effect. The physical solvent effect essentially refers to changes in the effective concentrations within the IL layer, while the ligand effect means that the IL can potentially bind to specific sites of the particle. The ligand effect can result in a change in the electron density of the metal or it can create a steric interference, in which case the adsorption of the incoming reactant is affected [22]. This interaction results in a chemical bond when the IL or its components adsorb onto a specific site [23,24]. Ni based SCILL catalysts have shown improved selectivity towards desired products as opposed to the traditional heterogeneous catalyst for cyclooctadiene hydrogenation [25]. Similar works using supported ionic liquid systems in selective hydrogenation using various active metals such as palladium-gold [26], palladium [20,27,28], nickel [29] and ruthenium [30] have been published. Studies of these systems examined the effect of the cation [31–35], anion [36–39] and the properties of the ionic liquids [40–42]. More specifically, SCILL catalysts were also investigated in competitive systems using octanal/octene hydrogenation [43] and 1-octyne/1,7-octadiene/1-octene hydrogenation [29]. Additionally, work done by Barth et al. [44] showed that SCILL catalysts improved the selectivity in butadiene hydrogenation, due to the metal-ionic liquid interaction of platinum and palladium. The aim of this study was to examine the effect of the IL on the catalytic behaviour of Cu on Al2O3 catalysts during the hydrogenation of octanal in the presence of octene as shown in Fig. 1 . Additionally, we investigated how the IL influences the reaction and how it affects the solid catalysts physico-chemical properties and the metal-ionic liquid interaction in SCILL systems. In this present work, 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium bis(trifluromethanesulfonyl)imide ([BMIM][NTf2]) was chosen as the IL. Imidazolium based ionic liquids have been extensively researched to understand the effect of anion [45], gas solubility [46], thermal stability [47–50], viscosity [51,52] etc. The solid catalyst component was also investigated by varying the preparation technique for the alumina supported copper catalysts. 2 Experimental Catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation using copper nitrate as the precursor salt. This was impregnated onto γ-Al2O3 to achieve the desired weight loading of 15 wt% Cu/Al2O3. For the one-step impregnation, the total amount required (15 wt% Cu) was introduced to the support (N15Cu). For the two-step impregnation, the alumina was impregnated first with 7.5 wt% followed by a calcination step, then a second addition of 7.5 wt% Cu followed by calcination gave 2N15Cu. The calcination was done at 500 °C for 8 h. The specific surface areas and porosity measurements were obtained using a Micromeritics TriStar II 3020 surface area and porosity instrument and associated software where the temperature was maintained at −195 °C. Prior to analysis, approximately 0.03 g of sample was degassed under nitrogen at 200 °C for 12 h. For TEM, a small amount of the sample was added to an Eppendorf vial with ethanol and the resultant mixture was sonicated for 5 min. The sample was added onto nickel grids and placed into a Jeol 1010 TEM instrument and analyzed using the Megaview III soft imaging system at an operating voltage of 100 kV. Back scattered electron (BSE) imaging and electron dispersive X-Ray spectroscopy (EDS) analyses were carried out on a Zeiss EVO 40 instrument that contained a tungsten filament. The BSE imaging and EDS mapping were done at an accelerating voltage of 20 kV and a probe current of 1.5 nA. The filament current was kept constant at 2.403 A. EDS analyses were performed using a Bruker XFlash SDD detector and Bruker Esprit software. The samples were cured with Akasel epoxy resin and Akasel cure, which were then polished using diamond paste and coated with carbon. Hydrogen Temperature Programmed Reduction (TPR) studies were conducted using a Micromeritics Autochem II Chemisorption Analyzer 2920 using ±0.03 g of sample. The method for the TPR analysis consisted of firstly heating the sample to 80 °C under a stream of He (10 mL/min) for 60 min, thereafter, the temperature was decreased to 50 °C under the same stream. The reduction experiments were carried out using 5 vol % H2 in Ar as the reducing agent with a flow rate of 5 mL/min to a temperature of 800 °C, ramped at 10 °C/min. The H2-TPD analysis using a Micromeritics Autochem 2920 was carried out by first reducing the catalyst with pure hydrogen at 220 °C (CuO/γ-Al2O3) for two hours. The catalyst was cooled to 50 °C under argon. The physisorbed hydrogen was removed by heating at 5 °C/min to the reduction temperature and holding at the reduction temperature for one hour. Thereafter, the sample was brought to and maintained at 120 °C under helium. Then 50 cm3/min of pure hydrogen was pulsed onto the catalyst’s surface and this was repeated 30 times with a four minute interval between each pulse to ensure complete saturation of the surface. After the pulse chemisorption, the temperature was raised to 160 °C at 10 °C/min under argon flow at a rate of 20 mL/min. Pulse chemisorption-TPD-MS studies were carried out on an AutoChem 2920 instrument coupled with Cirrus Mass Spectrometer (MKS Instruments) to study the Brønsted acid sites (BAS) present on the samples of interest. Approximately 300 mg of the sample was placed in quartz U-tube containing quartz wool, fitted with a thermocouple for continuous temperature measurements. The sample was activated first by heating to 220 °C at 10 °C /min in an inert argon environment and then cooled to 100 °C for pulse chemisorption consisting of 20 injections (1 cm³) of n-propylamine vapour which were dosed onto the sample in argon flow at 2 min intervals. The Brønsted acid sites’ analysis involved temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) from 100 to 160 °C at 10 °C/min, during which mass spectrometry (MS) was used to distinguish between the desorbing species (propylamine, propylene and ammonia). The mass of propylene desorbed was used to quantify the amount of Brønsted acid sites present, as deduced from the following equation: n-C3H7NH2 → NH3 + C3H6 The copper content of the samples was determined by ICP using an Optima 5300 DV PerkinElmer Optical Emission Spectrometer. Accurately weighed samples, with the approximate mass of ±0.02 g, were digested on a hotplate in 5 mL nitric acid, followed by filtration through a 0.45 μm filter. ICP standards ranging from 0 to 30 ppm were prepared from a Cu stock standard of 1000 ppm (Industrial Analytical, RSA). Analyses were carried out in duplicate. Hydrogen chemisorption experiments were carried out using ±0.03 g of samples that were degassed under a flow of N2 from RT to 200 °C. Upon reaching 200 °C, the samples were kept under vacuum for 12 h. These were analysed using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument. The sample was sandwiched between two layers of quartz wool in a quartz U-tube. The sample was initially reduced with H2 at 230 °C for 4 h. The hydrogen chemisorption capacity was determined by extrapolation of the hydrogen uptake to zero pressure. Chemisorption was used to determine the metal dispersion and crystallite size. XPS analyses were carried out on the PHI-TFA XPS spectrometer manufactured by Physical Electronics Inc. Sample powders were deposited on adhesive carbon tape and introduced into the ultra-high vacuum spectrometer. The vacuum during the XPS analyses was in the range of 10−9 mbar. The analyzed area was 0.4 mm in diameter and the analysis depth was about 3–5 nm. Sample surfaces were excited by X-ray radiation from a monochromatic Al source at a photon energy of 1486.6 eV. The high-energy resolution spectra were acquired with the energy analyzer operating at a resolution of about 0.6 eV and pass energy of 29 eV. During data processing the spectra from the surface were aligned by setting the C 1s peak at 285.0 eV, characteristic for CC bonds. The accuracy of binding energies was about ±0.3 eV. Three different XPS measurements were performed on each sample and the average composition was calculated. XP spectra were analyzed by a Multipak software, version 8.0 from the Physical Electronics Inc. Company. High resolution spectra were fitted with Gauss-Lorentz functions and the Shirley function was used for background removal. 2.1 Competitive hydrogenation of an octanal/octene mixture The catalytic studies were done in the liquid phase, using a continuous flow fixed bed reactor (Schematic presented in Fig. S1). The feed used comprised of 10 wt% octanal and 2 wt% 1-octene in a hexane mixture. Prior to catalytic testing, the catalysts were dried in the reactor under nitrogen at 25 mL/min at 200 °C for 12 h. The catalyst was reduced at 220 °C under 100% hydrogen flow at 30 mL/min for 12 h. Catalyst testing was done to optimize the best performing catalyst between N-15Cu and 2N-15Cu. The results comparing these two catalysts are shown in the Supplementary information. Reaction conditions were varied with temperatures between 120–180 °C and LHSV from 9 to 27 h−1, with the pressure of the reaction at 50 bar H2. All mass balances were between 97–101.5%, and all the results were obtained in at least duplicate. Eqs. (1)–(3) were used to calculate conversion and selectivity. Conversion was calculated from the difference in the initial reactant concentration and the final reactant concentration which is shown in the equation (1) C o n v e r s i o n = i n i t i a l m a s s o f r e a c t a n t i n - ( f i n a l m a s s o f r e a c t a n t o u t ) i n i t i a l m a s s o f r e a c t a n t i n × 100 (2) Corrected peak area = P e a k a r e a o f s i n g l e m o l e c u l e ∗ R f v a l u e ∗ Rf response factor = P e a k a r e a c o n c e n t r a t i o n value was obtained from GC calibrations for each identified component (3) M a s s % = c o r r e c t e d p e a k a r e a o f a s i n g l e p r o d u c t t o t a l p e a k a r e a f o r a l l p r o d u c t s For the SCILL catalyst preparation, after the reduction step, the ionic liquid, [BMIM][NTf2] (See Supplementary Fig. S2), was diluted in acetone and introduced to the reduced catalyst in a round bottom flask. The acetone was slowly evaporated under vacuum for 8 h, leaving behind a dry catalyst. The catalyst was then diluted with carborundum in a 50:50 ratio and dried under nitrogen at 90 °C for 2 h. 3 Characterization 3.1 TEM analysis Fig. 2 shows TEM images and particle size distribution for the 2N15Cu catalyst. Alumina has long rod like structures, while the copper crystallites are spherical in shape with varying sizes. Particle size distribution and metal dispersion data was obtained for both the N15Cu and 2N15Cu catalysts with the results presented in the Supplementary information Table S1 and Fig. S3. The 2N15Cu catalyst showed marginally better metal dispersion and particle size distribution, therefore further investigation was done using this catalyst. It is well documented that there is a strong correlation between crystallite size and catalyst activity [53]. Smaller particles have a greater metallic surface area and there is also an increase of steps, edges and defect sites, which are often more reactive than flat surfaces due to the decrease in binding energy to adsorb hydrogen and reactants [53]. Defect sites often have a higher affinity for adsorption compared to ideal crystalline surface planes and calculations have shown that kink sites can have a 44 times higher reaction rate compared to terrace sites [54,55]. Thus, preparing small well dispersed metal particles on the support is not only an efficient use of the active metal, but the formation of these defect sites assists in increasing catalyst activity. 3.2 SEM Fig. 3 shows the back scattered image of N15Cu and 2N15Cu. Fig. 4 A2-A3 and B2-B3 shows the elemental mapping of copper and aluminium. The results show that the metal is well distributed within the alumina particle in 2N15Cu. However, in the N15Cu catalyst, there are some regions of copper enrichment as well as some regions where copper is deficient, resulting in a heterogeneous distribution within the support particle. Minor regions of copper enrichment were also seen in 2N15Cu. These results are consisted with the data obtained from TEM analysis, where it was seen that the N15Cu catalysts had regions of higher metal density. TPR analysis showed two peaks in the reduction profile of each catalyst (Supplementary Fig. S4). The first peak (202–209 °C) is likely due to the formation of the Cu(I) species, whilst the second reduction peak may be due to the formation of metallic copper (233–238 °C). The slight differences in peak shapes and temperatures could be attributed to their particle size distribution. 2N15Cu having smaller particles could have a stronger interaction with the support, hence a slight shift to a higher reduction temperature was observed. Similar observations regarding copper reduction have been reported [56–58], although another perspective is described by Wang et al. [59]. In their work, they attributed the initial peak to the reduction of smaller, better dispersed crystallites and the second peak to bulk CuO reduction. Thus, it is also possible that the presence of multiple reduction peaks in the TPR profile is due to the reduction of CuO with different interactions with the support. Table 1 shows the reducibility of the N15Cu and 2N15Cu catalysts. As seen from the values calculated, there is still some unreduced CuO. This could be a result of the larger particles or bulk CuO that tend to be difficult to reduce [60]. The 2N15Cu catalyst has a slightly higher reducibility, which is a result of the smaller average crystallite size (from TEM). 3.3 Octanal/octene hydrogenation The desired product, formed from the hydrogenation of octanal is 1-octanol. The undesired product, from the 1-octene hydrogenation, is octane, which this work aimed to minimize. The support γ-alumina has acid and basic sites present which can result in side products being formed during the hydrogenation reaction as a result of aldol condensation of the octanal and octanol present. Fig. 4a shows the conversions obtained over 2N-15Cu for the competitive octanal and octene hydrogenation reaction. The conversions increased with the increase in temperature in the range tested between 120–180 °C. Additional catalytic data comparing the N15Cu and 2N15Cu are presented in Fig. S5. The 2N15Cu catalyst gave marginally better catalytic results, therefore all future testing was continued on this catalyst. Interestingly, the results show that the Cu/Al2O3 catalyst has a higher preference towards the CO adsorption and hydrogenation instead of the CC functional group present in octene. This is in line with many hydrogenolysis research papers where is was reported that copper has a higher preference towards CO adsorption over CC adsorption. The preference towards CO adsorption is attributed to its Lewis acidity which has a greater attraction towards the CO functional group than the CC functional group [11,12,61]. Fig. 4b shows the selectivity towards 1-octanol, which shows a higher selectivity over the 2N15Cu catalyst. The octanol selectivity increases as the temperature increases, which is attributed to the increased energy supplied to the system causing an increased rate of adsorption and desorption, which will reduce additional side product formation. The higher metal dispersion on 2N15Cu decreases the number of exposed alumina sites (acidic) over which the aldol condensation can occur. The major by-product obtained was C16 diol and negligible quantities of C24 acetals were also seen. It is also important to note that no octane is formed from the hydrogenation of octanal as previously established [1]. 3.3.1 Effect of ionic liquid on 2N15Cu SCILL Since the characterization and catalytic testing showed marginally better results for 2N15Cu than N15Cu, the SCILL catalyst was prepared by coating the 2N15Cu catalyst with [BMIM][NTf2]. The quantity of ionic liquid coated on the catalyst was varied to determine an optimal ionic liquid weight loading. Due to the viscous nature of the ionic liquid, some internal mass transfer limitations within the ionic liquid layer are possible, where the reactant concentration within the pores are lower than on the surface [62]. This was also investigated by examining the effect of space velocity. Additional characterization of the catalyst which includes XRD, light microscopy and HRTEM-EDS can be found in the Supplementary information Figs. S11–S15. 3.3.2 Effect of weight loading Fig. 5 depicts the effect of ionic liquid weight loading on the competitive octanal/octene hydrogenation over the 2N15Cu SCILL catalyst. It is seen that there is a decrease in octanal conversion with the increase in weight loading from 98.9% to 93% for the uncoated catalyst and 20 wt% IL loading respectively. The slight decrease in octanal conversion could be attributed to a combination of internal mass transfer limitations of the reactants and hydrogen gas within the ionic liquid layer as mentioned by Hou et al. [20]. It has been well documented that due to the viscous nature of ionic liquids, there is a significant decrease of hydrogen solubility as compared to conventional solvents [63]. Lei and co-workers summarized gas solubilities in various ionic liquids, where the hydrogen solubility in [BMIM][NTf2] at 160 °C at 46.8 bar is 0.035, and the solubility increases with pressure [64,65]. However, at steady state, the hydrogen solubility did not significantly affect the conversions as observed from the results in Fig. 5 as the octanol selectivity obtained remained near constant, which ranged from 99.1 to 99.8%. Therefore, internal mass transfer limitations due to the ionic liquid layer resulted in a decrease in octanal conversion from 98.9% to 93% as the weight loading of ionic liquid increased. There was a significant decrease in the octene conversion over the 5 wt% IL coated catalyst (11.5%) compared to the uncoated catalyst (39%). A further decrease in octene conversion is observed when the IL weight loading was increased to 10 wt% (6%). However, further increases in the IL content (20 wt%) showed no further decrease thus indicating that a limit is reached after which the ionic liquid no longer alters the activity. Hence, the optimal IL weight loading required to achieve best competitive catalytic hydrogenation was 10 wt%. This result also supports work done by the Haumann et al. [66], who found that weight loadings below 10 wt% ionic liquid could result in incomplete coverage of the ionic liquid, forming uncoated islands in certain areas. 3.4 SEM: 10% [BMIM] [NTf2] on 2N15Cu To determine the IL coverage, SEM-EDS line scans were done on the coated catalyst before and after the reaction over the 2N15Cu SCILL catalyst (containing 10 wt% IL). Slight agglomeration of copper on the used catalyst was seen from regions of higher metal density, however, there was no change in catalyst activity over the duration of the reaction. The results, shown in Fig. 6 , show a fairly uniform coverage of the ionic liquid where sulfur was used to identify the presence of the IL ([BMIM][NTf2]). 3.5 Effect of space velocity As the space velocity was increased, the octanal conversion decreased from 96% at 9 h−1 to 12% at 27 h−1 LHSV, (Fig. 7 ), due to the decreased contact time between the reactants and the active sites. There was no significant change to the octanol selectivity. Interestingly, irrespective of the LHSV used, the octene conversion remained fairly constant, which ranged between 4–6% with the only significant change occurring at 27 h−1 LHSV where it decreased to 0.2%. This indicates that the ionic liquid plays a significant role in controlling and preventing the adsorption of octene. Similar observations of preferential adsorption of different functional groups have been described by various authors [23,46,67]. As shown in Fig. 5, the viscous nature of [BMIM][NTf2] resulted in internal mass transfer limitations as the diffusion of the reactants within the ionic liquid layer was slow resulting in a decreased effective reactant concentration on the SCILL catalyst leading to lower conversions. 3.6 SCILL catalyst stability It is theoretically possible, since the IL used in this work ([BMIM][NTf2]) is soluble in polar solvents, that the major product, octanol, could wash out the IL over time. Fig. 8 shows the time on line study over the 10% IL loaded 2N15Cu SCILL catalyst. The high octanal conversion and octanol selectivity was maintained, as was the low octene conversion. This implies that the IL modification of the catalyst surface, hence the preferential adsorption and hydrogenation of octanal over octene, is stable under the reaction conditions (72 h). The use of hexane as the solvent may assist in creating an immiscible barrier around the ionic liquid-liquid feed interface preventing the ionic liquid from being leached. Fig. 9 illustrates the different interfaces present on a SCILL particle. There is still uncertainty about the manner in which the ionic liquid interacts with the active site, however, it has been reported that this could either be a “ligand type” or a “physical solvent” effect or both [22,67]. Octanal is more polar than octene, therefore it is expected that octanal has a greater solubility than octene within the ionic liquid layer, this was confirmed by a solvation test of [BMIM][NTf2] in octanal, octene and hexane which is shown in the Supplementary material, Fig. S6. Low solubility of a certain reactant within the ionic liquid layer can prevent or minimize this reactant interacting with the active site and in extreme cases may completely prevent its diffusion within the ionic liquid layer, averting adsorption and hydrogenation completely. There was also a significant increase in the octanol selectivity over the 2N15Cu SCILL catalyst compared to the 2N15Cu (uncoated) catalyst (99.9 vs. 93.5% respectively). Thus, the IL modification hinders re-adsorption of the primary products onto the acid and basic sites of alumina, thus preventing secondary reactions such as aldol condensation. In addition to the different solubilities of octanal and octene within the ionic liquid layer, the ionic liquid can hinder certain sites due to an interaction between the imidazolium component of the IL and the active site, which would affect the adsorption modes between the incoming reactants and the active site, as described by Sobota et al. [23]. Since a flat surface favours CC bond adsorption, the presence of the ionic liquid might limit access of octene to the metal due to the steric bulk of [BMIM][NTf2]. The steric bulk of the ionic liquid can bring about changes in the mode of adsorption between the reactants and the active site. The atop mode for the CO bond would be more favourable because the vertical mode occupies less space on the surface than the parallel adsorption modes of octene. Similar observations have been made when comparing modes of carbonyl adsorption between Cu, Pt and Pd [5]. To investigate the nature and type of interaction between the ionic liquid and the solid catalyst, the solvent was changed from hexane to octanol. In the case of the “ligand-type” interaction, the ionic liquid can act as a reservoir to provide the necessary amount of the required molecule to adsorb and form a bond with the active metal. If this interaction results in a (stable) chemical bond, then once the excess ionic liquid is washed away, the catalytic activity would remain the same. In the case of a “physical solvent effect”, once the ionic liquid is washed away, the catalytic activity would be comparable to that of the uncoated catalyst. Fig. 10 summarizes of the reactions comparing the uncoated 2N15Cu, 2N15Cu SCILL (hexane solvent), and 2N15Cu SCILL (octanol washed). For the 2N15Cu SCILL (OL washed), the increase in octene conversion from 6%, over the 2N15Cu SCILL, to 35% indicates that the octanol feed washes away the ionic liquid leaving behind the solid catalyst. This confirms that the ionic liquid has a weak interaction with the catalyst surface, possibly van de Waals interactions. The effect in this catalyst system is therefore a physical solvent effect, since the octene conversion with octanol as the solvent, is comparable to that of the uncoated 2N15Cu catalyst. A similar effect is observed with the octanal conversion, whereby the 2N15Cu SCILL (OL washed) gave a 2% higher octanal conversion as compared to the 2N15Cu SCILL catalyst. The higher conversion of octene in the octanol solvent compared to the hexane solvent could be a result of the higher hydrogen solubility in the polar solvent, resulting in an increase in the rate of reaction (see Supplementary information Table S2) [68]. 3.7 Used catalyst characterization The surface properties of the fresh and used uncoated and SCILL catalyst are summarized in Table 2 . The addition of the metal on the alumina decreases the surface area and porosity as a result of the filling of pores by the active metal. For SCILL catalysts, the significant decrease of surface area and pore volume further confirms the ionic liquid coating the surface of the catalyst. When comparing the used uncoated catalyst to the fresh uncoated catalyst, the surface area is further decreased likely as a result of organics still present on the catalyst. The 2N15Cu SCILL used catalyst still has a significantly lower surface area than the used uncoated catalyst confirming that the ionic liquid is still present on the catalyst after the reaction. The 2N15Cu SCILL (OL washed) showed a surface area that was comparable to the surface area of the used uncoated catalyst, with additional surface area analysis information presented in Fig. S7. This further confirms that the ionic liquid is physically adsorbed to the surface, as opposed to a chemisorbed “ligand type effect”, and can be easily removed by changing the solvent from hexane to octanol. IR analysis was also done on the fresh, SCILL and SCILL (OL washed) samples, shown in Supplementary information Fig. S8, which supports the results obtained from surface area analysis. There are some reports on the dissociation and adsorption of hydrogen on copper to differentiate the possible sites and their respective binding energies [69–72]. Cooper et al. [73] showed that the surface and subsurface hydrogen species play a major role in the partial hydrogenation of 1,3 butadiene. It was shown that the presence of subsurface carbon decreased the surface hydrogen coverage which led to the catalyst being more effective as a partial hydrogenation catalyst. There is a significant difference in the hydrogen desorption profile between the uncoated 2N15Cu catalyst, the 2N15Cu SCILL catalyst and the used 2N15Cu SCILL (OL washed) as shown in Supplementary Fig. S9. Hydrogen desorption occurs slightly faster for the 2N15Cu SCILL catalyst compared to the uncoated 2N15Cu catalyst, indicating that hydrogen may have a weaker interaction in the presence of the ionic liquid or this can be a result of competing adsorption between the hydrogen and ionic liquid. Interestingly, the used 2N15Cu SCILL (OL washed) was shown by BET to have lost the ionic liquid, yet its hydrogen desorption profile is not comparable to that of the uncoated 2N15Cu catalyst. This shows that, whilst the BET surface area was regained, the active sites on the surface may have been altered, indicative of a “ligand effect”. Table 3 shows the quantity of hydrogen desorbed, in the following order of hydrogen desorption, 2N15Cu > 2N15Cu SCILL > 2N15Cu SCILL (OL washed). The decrease in hydrogen desorption on the 2N15Cu SCILL catalyst shows that the presence of the ionic liquid restricts hydrogen interaction on the catalyst surface. Interestingly, 2N15Cu SCILL (OL washed) did not regain the hydrogen desorption values of the uncoated catalyst, unlike the surface area analysis. This suggests that the IL modification is irreversible, which is supported by the unchanged product selectivity from the octanal conversion between the 2N15CU SCILL catalyst and the 2N15Cu SCILL (OL washed) catalyst. Decreasing the Brønsted acidity of a catalyst is assumed to withdraw electron density from the supported metal particles, thus weakening the metal-hydrogen bond. Higher acidity means greater electron density. This increased electron density reduces the binding energy required to adsorb hydrogen and reactants, resulting in an increased rate of reaction [74–76]. Alumina is a well-known Lewis acidic material, therefore any Brønsted acidity is a result of the supported copper nanoparticles that are able to dissociate hydrogen resulting in Brønsted acid sites on the catalyst surface via hydrogen spill over [77]. It was shown that the 2N15Cu SCILL catalyst has significantly less Brønsted acidity compared to the 2N15Cu catalyst (Table 3). Additional BAS information is given in Fig. S10. This could be a result of the electronic effect between the π-electrons available on the imidazolium cation of the ionic liquid, which supplied electron density to the supported metal resulting in a decrease of acidity, which indicates the SCILL catalyst system could have some ligand effect contributions in addition to the physical solvent effect. Cation exchange between the ionic liquid and zeolites has been seen in work done by Hardacre and co-workers, which is an example of a ligand effect between the ionic liquid and material [78]. In this work, there does not seem to be evidence for the permanent ionic exchange between the ionic liquid and Cu/Al2O3 catalyst as seen from the Cu SCILL (OL washed) catalytic results. The decrease in the byproduct selectivity could also be a result of the decreased acidity on the 2N15Cu SCILL catalyst, as it is known that the initial activation for aldol condensation occurs via hydrogen activation on Brønsted sites [79]. This result also correlates with the hydrogen desorption trends between the uncoated 2N15Cu and the 2N15Cu SCILL catalyst. The 2N15Cu SCILL (OL washed) regained some acidity which correlated to the higher conversions associated with the octanol washed catalyst. Due to the Brønsted acidity still being lower than of the 2N15Cu catalyst, this corresponds to the high selectivity towards octanol as there are now fewer Brønsted sites to promote the aldol condensation reactions. 3.7.1 XPS Figs. 11 and 12 show the XP Spectra of the individual elements in the catalyst. For the uncoated catalysts, the Cu, Al, and O spectra are shown, while the C, N, S, F, and O spectra are shown for the ionic liquid coated catalysts. The deviation in the peak signals compared to what is reported in literature falls within the range of expected variance using different spectrometers. The Al 2p spectrum in Fig. 12b shows the main signal at 72.5 eV and a smaller peak 75.5 eV. The main peak is attributed to the Al2O3 support, with the high B.E. peak attributed to aluminium bonded to copper, as that is likely to take place during impregnation, and it is seen for both the uncoated and coated samples. The Cu 2p XP spectra revealed the presence of Cu(0), Cu(I), and Cu(II). The catalyst was reduced prior to the introduction of the ionic liquid, and this was compared to a reduced uncoated catalyst. The presence of Cu(I) and Cu(II) indicates that the copper nanoparticles oxidize under atmospheric oxygen as no special care was taken to maintain an inert environment for the samples tested. The dominant peak occurs at ∼932 eV for the 2p 3/2 spin orbital which could be attributed to Cu(0) and/or Cu(I). It is difficult to differentiate between the Cu(0) and Cu(I) due to the small difference in binding energy. The 2p 1/2 spin orbital peak is at ∼ 952 eV which is also attributed to Cu(0) or Cu(I). There are also Cu(II) peaks at ∼940 eV and ∼960 eV due to the oxidation of the copper nanoparticles [80–82]. The O 1 s signal shows contributions from the Al2O3 support and the [NTf2]-anion. One peak is seen for the 2N15Cu catalyst (Fig. 11e), while 2N15Cu SCILL shows 3 peaks at 528.1, 529.7, 531.8 eV. The main peak at 529.7 eV is due to the ionic liquid, while the lower B.E. component is a result of acetone present. The higher B.E. component is attributed to the Al2O3. This is consistent with previous XPS studies on [EMIM][NTf2] and [BMIM][NTf2] [23,83]. Interestingly, for the used catalyst, there was only one peak observed at 529.8 eV with no additional peaks seen for the Al2O3 support contribution. This is likely a result of the IL thickness on the sample examined which is greater than that of the sample of the unused 2N15Cu SCILL catalyst, indicating the catalyst does not have uniform IL coverage, with some regions thicker than others. There are five different chemical environments associated with carbon with the adsorbed ionic liquid, as described by Beattie et al. [84]. The first C signal is attributed to the CF3 functional group in the anion at 287.1 eV. The four other signals come from the BMIM+ cation which is (a) carbon from the butyl chain, (b) carbon bonded with one nitrogen in the imidazolium ring, (c) carbon bonded to nitrogen on the methyl chain and (d) carbon bonded to two nitrogen atoms in the imidazolium ring, commonly referred to as the C2H position. Due to the extremely close binding energies, there is an overlap of these environments, resulting in two main peaks. The peak at 284.6 eV is attributed to the carbon directly bound to nitrogen (Chetero), and the peak at 282.6 eV is due to the other carbon atoms on the alkyl chain (Calkyl) as shown in Fig. 12b [23]. In the 2N15Cu SCILL used catalyst, 5 peaks are observed as shown in Fig. 12c. The additional peaks at 282.4 and 284.3 eV could be attributed to the adsorbed reactants still present within the ionic liquid layer or on the catalyst. One peak, at the higher B.E., could be attributed to carbonyl containing molecules, such as octanal, or octanol. The lower B.E. component is due to the presence of octene or octane. Fig. 12a shows the signal for the N 1s. Two signals are expected due to the NTf2 − and BMIM+ components. However, the XP spectrum shows one broad signal, which could be attributed to a thin layer of IL on the support, as described by Cremer et al. [83], where two distinct peaks only occur as the IL layer thickness increases. There were also changes observed for the S 2p signal. For the 2N15Cu SCILL catalyst, there are four peaks, related to the SO2 functional group in the NTf2 − anion. The peak signals at 163.7 and 164.4 eV are due to the single spin-orbit split signal. Additional peaks can be attributed to the adsorbed SO2, fluorinated sulfur, and SOxFy species due to the possible decomposition of the NTf2 − component [23]. In the 2N15Cu SCILL used catalyst, there are two signals observed, which are at 164.1 and 165.8 eV. This indicates that the additional sulfur species have been removed during the reaction, but there are still adsorbed SO2 and the SO2 from the NTf2 −, indicating that the majority of the ionic liquid remains intact. The F 1s signal of the 2N15Cu SCILL catalyst shows two peaks which are attributed to the CF3 on the NTf2 − anion (686.0 e.V.) and the minor peak at 688.4 eV to the fluorinated sulfur. The 2N15Cu SCILL used catalyst only shows one peak at 686.0 eV due to the CF3 group. This is consistent with the results obtained from the S 2p spectra, where a small amount of fluorinated sulfur species is likely removed during the reaction. The findings from XPS analysis reveal that the majority of the ionic liquid remains unaltered during the reaction. There was partial decomposition of the NTf2 − anion which resulted in adsorption of SO2 and fluorinated sulfur species which get removed during the reaction. The results show no significant change with regards to the BMIM+ cation component, however, there was a change in the NTf2 − anion, which could be due to its more electronegative atoms, whereby fragmentation and decomposition is favoured to form smaller stable inorganic molecules [23]. 4 Summary Results show that the interaction between the bulk ionic liquid and metal is fairly weak and that the “physical solvent effect” dominates, since the use of octanol as a solvent gave similar activity as the uncoated 2N15Cu catalyst. Various characterization techniques supported the findings, for example N2-physisorption results showed the surface area of the 2N15Cu SCILL (OL Washed) was similar to that of the uncoated 2N15Cu catalyst. H2-TPD results indicated that the IL changes the metal-hydrogen interaction on the 2N15Cu SCILL catalyst which does not regain the original surface acidity of the uncoated catalyst once the ionic liquid is removed. n-Propylamine TPD results showed a change in acidity brought about by the introduction of ionic liquid, which could be a major factor affecting the change in catalyst activity as well as the improved selectivity towards 1-octanol. XPS results obtained further proved that the IL is physically adsorbed onto the 2N15Cu catalyst, in addition confirming that the majority of the IL is stable and unaltered even after the reaction. 5 Conclusion Comparing N15Cu and 2N15Cu showed that the preparation method does play a role in the properties of the material in terms of particle size, metal dispersion and reducibility. The higher metal dispersion of the 2N15Cu catalyst results in better catalytic performance than the N15Cu catalyst. The 2N15Cu catalyst was also more selective in adsorbing and hydrogenating the octanal substrate over octene. The 2N15Cu SCILL catalyst containing 10 wt% ionic liquid was shown to have a fairly uniform IL coverage as determined from the SEM-EDS line scan. The SCILL catalyst improved the selectivity of the octanal adsorption and hydrogenation, while the octene conversion decreased considerably from 26% (uncoated 2N15Cu) to 6% (2N15Cu SCILL). Additionally, an improved octanol selectivity was obtained using the SCILL catalyst as a result of the ionic liquid coating the surface of the catalyst, thus preventing re-adsorption of the alcohol. Also the decreased acidity prevented aldol condensation from taking place. The surface of the SCILL catalyst is very complex in nature with many contributing factors, such as surface area, IL weight loading, acidity, and the nature of the interface between the ionic liquid and the active metal. The SCILL catalyst showed good chemical and thermal stability as determined from surface area analysis, time-on-line results and XPS analysis. The combination of catalytic testing and the characterization techniques implemented showed that the interaction between the copper and ionic liquid is a result of physical adsorption of the IL. The change in catalytic performance is most likely due to a physical solvent effect brought about by the steric bulk of the ionic liquid which favours the end on adsorption of the aldehyde functional group over the alkene group. coredata.dc:description: The influence of 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium bis(trifluromethanesulfonyl)imide ([BMIM][NTf2]) on Cu/γ-Al2O3 was investigated for the competitive hydrogenation of octanal in the presence of octene in a continuous flow reactor. The role of the solid catalyst was investigated by comparing the activities of one-step (N15Cu) vs two step (2N15Cu) wet impregnated catalyst. Characterization techniques included nitrogen physisorption, temperature programmed studies, electron microscopy and X-Ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy which were used to determine the catalyst properties and metal-ionic liquid interaction of the uncoated and IL coated catalysts. The Cu SCILL catalyst (solid catalyst with an ionic liquid layer) showed enhanced catalytic performance as compared to the uncoated catalyst. Under optimized conditions, the 2N15Cu SCILL catalyst favoured the desired hydrogenation of the octanal, whilst minimizing the undesired octene hydrogenation. The octene conversion decreased from 26% to 6% over the SCILL catalyst. The presence of the ionic liquid also increased the selectivity towards the desired product, 1-octanol, from 93.5% over the uncoated catalyst to 99.8% over the SCILL catalyst. Investigation into the interaction between the copper and the ionic liquid revealed that the ionic liquid is physically adsorbed onto the catalyst’s surface, and induced changes in the SCILL catalysts surface acidity, BET surface area and hydrogen-metal interaction. It seems likely that the thermal and chemical properties of the ionic liquid also contributed to the SCILL catalyst behaviour, for example, the polar nature of the ionic liquid favours the diffusion of octanal as opposed to octene within the ionic liquid layer. This results in a greater selectivity towards CO hydrogenation which is desired.
coredata.dc:title: The effect of ionic liquid on alumina supported copper catalysts for the competitive hydrogenation of octanal in the presence of octene
